title: Isaiah Chapter 63 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 63 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 63 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 63.

questions.question: Who is described as coming from Edom with dyed garments from Bozrah?
options: The one glorious in his apparel
Moses
The angel of the LORD
The shepherd of his flock
questions.correctAnswer: The one glorious in his apparel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:1 describes the one coming from Edom with dyed garments from Bozrah as glorious in his apparel.

questions.question: What is the reason given for the red color of the garments in Isaiah 63:2?
options: Like him that treadeth in the winefat
Dyed with scarlet thread
Stained by battle
From the soil of Edom
questions.correctAnswer: Like him that treadeth in the winefat
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:2 asks why the apparel is red and explains it is like him that treadeth in the winefat.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:3, who did the speaker tread the winepress with?
options: Alone, with none of the people with him
With Moses and the people
With the angel of the LORD
With the shepherd of his flock
questions.correctAnswer: Alone, with none of the people with him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:3 states the speaker trod the winepress alone and of the people there was none with him.

questions.question: What has come according to Isaiah 63:4?
options: The year of the redeemed
The day of peace
The season of harvest
The time of exile
questions.correctAnswer: The year of the redeemed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:4 says the day of vengeance is in God's heart and the year of his redeemed has come.

questions.question: What upheld the speaker when there was none to help, as per Isaiah 63:5?
options: Mine own arm and fury
The people of Israel
The angel of his presence
The shepherd of his flock
questions.correctAnswer: Mine own arm and fury
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:5 explains that when there was none to help, the speaker's own arm brought salvation and fury upheld him.

questions.question: What will the speaker do to the people in his anger according to Isaiah 63:6?
options: Tread them down and make them drunk in fury
Lead them to the promised land
Protect them with his glorious arm
Comfort them with lovingkindness
questions.correctAnswer: Tread them down and make them drunk in fury
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:6 says the speaker will tread down the people in anger and make them drunk in fury.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:7, what will the speaker mention?
options: The lovingkindnesses and praises of the LORD
The sins of Israel
The days of exile
The strength of Edom
questions.correctAnswer: The lovingkindnesses and praises of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:7 states the speaker will mention the lovingkindnesses and praises of the LORD.

questions.question: Who does God say are His people in Isaiah 63:8?
options: Children that will not lie
The adversaries
The people of Edom
The shepherd of his flock
questions.correctAnswer: Children that will not lie
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:8 says God called them His people, children that will not lie.

questions.question: How did God respond to the affliction of His people according to Isaiah 63:9?
options: He was afflicted with them and the angel of his presence saved them
He abandoned them to their enemies
He punished them with famine
He sent prophets to rebuke them
questions.correctAnswer: He was afflicted with them and the angel of his presence saved them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:9 states that in all their affliction, God was afflicted and the angel of his presence saved them.

questions.question: What did the people do to God's holy Spirit according to Isaiah 63:10?
options: They rebelled and vexed the holy Spirit
They honored and obeyed the holy Spirit
They ignored the holy Spirit
They followed the holy Spirit faithfully
questions.correctAnswer: They rebelled and vexed the holy Spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:10 says the people rebelled and vexed God's holy Spirit.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 63:12 speaks about God leading the people by the right hand of Moses and dividing the waters before them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:12 describes God leading the people by Moses' right hand and dividing the water before them.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 63:13 compares God's leading of the people through the deep to a horse in the wilderness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:13 compares God's leading of the people through the deep to a horse in the wilderness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 63:16, Abraham is acknowledged by God as the father of the people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:16 says though Abraham is ignorant of the people and Israel acknowledges them not, God is their father.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 63:17: 'O LORD, why hast thou made us to err from thy _______, and hardened our heart from thy fear?'
options: ways
laws
promises
commands
questions.correctAnswer: ways
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:17 asks why God made the people err from His ways and hardened their hearts from His fear.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:19, who has never borne rule over the people?
options: Their adversaries
The LORD
Moses
The angel of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Their adversaries
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:19 states that their adversaries never bore rule over the people and were not called by God's name.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 63 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 63 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels overwhelmed by God’s discipline and wonders why God’s Spirit seems absent. Based on Isaiah 63, what biblical truth about God’s discipline and mercy would you share?
options: God disciplines because of our rebellion but remains loving and merciful toward His people.
God abandons His people when they sin and does not remember His covenant.
God’s anger is final and means there is no hope for restoration.
God only shows mercy to perfect believers without sin.
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines because of our rebellion but remains loving and merciful toward His people.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:9-11 reveal that though the people rebelled and vexed the Spirit (v.10), God’s love and pity led Him to redeem and carry them (v.9), showing His enduring mercy despite discipline (v.10-11).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 63 teach us about trusting God’s strength during personal trials?
options: God’s own arm brings salvation and upholds us in fury and strength.
We must rely solely on human help and strength in times of trouble.
God is distant and does not intervene in our afflictions.
Strength comes from ignoring God and focusing on self.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s own arm brings salvation and upholds us in fury and strength.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:5 states that when there was none to help, God’s own arm brought salvation and upheld the speaker in fury, demonstrating God’s power and faithfulness in trials (v.1-6).

questions.question: A believer struggles to forgive others because of past hurts. According to Isaiah 63, what understanding about God’s forgiveness should encourage them?
options: God’s lovingkindness and mercies are abundant and everlasting toward His people.
Forgiveness is only for those who never sin again.
God withholds mercy because of repeated offenses.
Only some people are worthy of God’s forgiveness.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s lovingkindness and mercies are abundant and everlasting toward His people.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:7-8 highlights the multitude of God’s lovingkindnesses and great goodness toward Israel, assuring believers of His abundant mercy (v.7-8).

questions.question: What biblical principle about humility and reliance on God’s help can be learned from Isaiah 63:5?
options: When no one helps, we must depend on God’s saving arm rather than our own strength.
We should pridefully trust our own resources before seeking God’s help.
God only helps those who never face difficulties.
Self-reliance is more important than trusting God.
questions.correctAnswer: When no one helps, we must depend on God’s saving arm rather than our own strength.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:5 emphasizes that when there was no help, God's own arm brought salvation, teaching humility and dependence on God (v.1-6).

questions.question: A family is facing hardship and doubts God’s care. Based on Isaiah 63, how would you counsel them about God’s faithfulness?
options: God has always carried and redeemed His people with love and pity.
God abandons families in hardship without concern.
God only cares about individuals, not families.
God’s help is conditional on perfect obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: God has always carried and redeemed His people with love and pity.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:9 states God was afflicted with His people’s affliction and bore them with love and pity all days of old, showing His faithfulness (v.9).

questions.question: How does this chapter teach about God’s role as our Redeemer and Father despite human failure?
options: God is our Father and Redeemer even if Abraham and Israel do not acknowledge us.
God only accepts those who are perfect and acknowledge Him.
God’s relationship depends on human recognition alone.
God abandons those who fail to honor their heritage.
questions.correctAnswer: God is our Father and Redeemer even if Abraham and Israel do not acknowledge us.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:16 affirms God as our Father and Redeemer regardless of human ignorance or rejection, emphasizing His eternal care (v.16).

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 63, God’s anger toward His people means He ceases to love or care for them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:10-11 shows that although the people rebelled and God’s Spirit was vexed, He still remembered them, showing His continuing love and care despite anger (v.10-11).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 63 teaches that God’s vengeance and salvation go hand in hand as part of His justice and mercy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:3-4 describe God’s vengeance in His heart alongside the year of His redeemed coming, showing the balance of justice and salvation (v.3-4).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 63 illustrate the importance of remembering God’s past works in sustaining faith?
options: Remembering God’s deliverance through Moses strengthens trust in His present help.
Focusing on past failures is more important than God’s works.
God’s past works are irrelevant to current faith.
Faith depends only on feelings, not on remembering God’s deeds.
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering God’s deliverance through Moses strengthens trust in His present help.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:11-14 recalls God’s past leadership through Moses and His Spirit, encouraging believers to trust Him now by remembering His faithfulness (v.11-14).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness after being hurt by others. According to Isaiah 63, what biblical attitude toward God’s justice and mercy should be encouraged?
options: Trust that God will execute justice in His timing while showing mercy to His people.
Take personal revenge immediately instead of trusting God.
Ignore God’s justice and focus only on mercy for self.
Doubt that God cares about justice or mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will execute justice in His timing while showing mercy to His people.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:4-6 shows God’s day of vengeance and mercy coinciding as He acts in anger but also brings salvation, encouraging trust in His righteous justice (v.4-6).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 63 teach about God’s persistent zeal and mercy even when His people feel abandoned?
options: God’s zeal and mercies are not restrained though His people may feel distant from Him.
God loses zeal and mercy when people sin.
God’s mercy is limited and sometimes withheld permanently.
God’s zeal is only for the righteous and not for sinners.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s zeal and mercies are not restrained though His people may feel distant from Him.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:15 questions God’s zeal and mercy, implying their presence despite feelings of distance, revealing God’s ongoing compassion (v.15).

questions.question: How does this chapter encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in difficult times?
options: God’s saving arm upholds those who trust Him honestly even when no human help is available.
Integrity is not important when facing overwhelming opposition.
Honesty is only for easy circumstances.
God favors only those who pretend to be strong.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s saving arm upholds those who trust Him honestly even when no human help is available.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:5 highlights that when no help was available, God’s arm saved and upheld the speaker, encouraging trust and honesty in God’s support (v.5).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 63:7, we should mention the _______ of the LORD and His praises because of His great goodness and mercies.
options: lovingkindnesses
wrath
judgments
punishments
questions.correctAnswer: lovingkindnesses
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:7 teaches us to remember and praise the LORD’s lovingkindnesses and great goodness toward His people, highlighting gratitude and faithfulness (v.7).

questions.question: How can Isaiah 63 guide believers in serving others in the church during times of trial?
options: By remembering God’s past faithfulness and showing mercy as He does.
By focusing only on personal needs and ignoring others.
By criticizing those who struggle instead of helping.
By expecting God to serve us without our involvement.
questions.correctAnswer: By remembering God’s past faithfulness and showing mercy as He does.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:7-9 encourages recalling God’s mercy and redeeming love, which inspires believers to extend mercy and faithful service to one another (v.7-9).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 63 teach about the importance of prayer and seeking God’s presence in times of confusion and wandering?
options: We should look to God’s holiness and glory, asking for His zeal and mercy to return.
Prayer is unnecessary since God does not respond.
We should rely on ourselves without seeking God.
God’s presence is only for the righteous and not those who wander.
questions.correctAnswer: We should look to God’s holiness and glory, asking for His zeal and mercy to return.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:15-17 models praying for God to look down from heaven and restore His zeal and mercy when His people have erred and hardened their hearts (v.15-17).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 63 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 63.

questions.question: Who is described as coming from Edom with dyed garments from Bozrah, glorious in apparel and mighty to save?
options: The Messiah
The prophet Isaiah
A conquering king
The angel of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The Messiah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:1 depicts a figure coming from Edom with dyed garments from Bozrah, glorious and mighty to save, which is widely interpreted as a Messianic figure.

questions.question: What is the significance of the figure's red garments in Isaiah 63:2-3?
options: They symbolize the blood of the winepress he has trodden.
They signify royal authority and kingship.
They indicate mourning and sorrow.
They represent the fire of divine wrath.
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize the blood of the winepress he has trodden.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:2-3 describes red garments like one who treads in the winefat, symbolizing blood from the winepress trodden in anger and fury.

questions.question: In Isaiah 63:4, what has come according to the speaker's heart?
options: The day of vengeance and the year of the redeemed
The day of peace and the year of prosperity
The day of exile and the year of captivity
The day of judgment and the year of destruction
questions.correctAnswer: The day of vengeance and the year of the redeemed
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states that the day of vengeance is in the speaker's heart and the year of the redeemed has come, indicating divine justice and salvation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:5, who brought salvation to the speaker when none helped or upheld him?
options: His own arm
The people of Israel
The angel of the LORD
The prophet Moses
questions.correctAnswer: His own arm
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:5 explains that when there was no help, the speaker's own arm brought salvation, emphasizing self-reliance of divine power.

questions.question: Which theme is prominently expressed in Isaiah 63:6 regarding the speaker's attitude toward the people?
options: Judgment through anger and fury
Compassion and forgiveness
Patience and long-suffering
Joy and celebration
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment through anger and fury
questions.explanation: Verse 6 clearly presents the theme of judgment, describing treading down the people in anger and making them drunk in fury.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 63:7 emphasize about the LORD's character toward Israel?
options: His lovingkindness and great goodness
His wrath and judgment
His silence and abandonment
His strict law and justice
questions.correctAnswer: His lovingkindness and great goodness
questions.explanation: Verse 7 praises the LORD's lovingkindness and mercies bestowed on Israel, highlighting divine compassion.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:8, how does the LORD regard the people described as 'children that will not lie'?
options: As His people, whom He saves
As strangers and foreigners
As rebellious and unworthy
As servants bound to Him
questions.correctAnswer: As His people, whom He saves
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states that the LORD said 'Surely they are my people' and He was their Saviour, affirming their special relationship.

questions.question: Isaiah 63:9 describes the LORD’s presence during affliction. How is this presence characterized?
options: The LORD was afflicted with them and saved them through the angel of His presence
The LORD abandoned them to their fate
The LORD punished them severely
The LORD hid His face and refused to hear
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD was afflicted with them and saved them through the angel of His presence
questions.explanation: Verse 9 indicates the LORD’s empathy and active salvation through His angel during their afflictions.

questions.question: What is the consequence of the people's rebellion as described in Isaiah 63:10?
options: The LORD was turned into their enemy and fought against them
The LORD forgave and restored them
The LORD sent prophets to warn them
The LORD withdrew His Spirit from the land
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD was turned into their enemy and fought against them
questions.explanation: Verse 10 explains that because of rebellion and vexing the holy Spirit, the LORD became an enemy and fought against them.

questions.question: Isaiah 63:11-12 recalls the LORD’s past acts with Moses. Which event is explicitly referenced?
options: The parting of the Red Sea
The giving of the Ten Commandments
The manna in the wilderness
The battle against Amalek
questions.correctAnswer: The parting of the Red Sea
questions.explanation: Verse 12 speaks of dividing the waters before them, a clear allusion to the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea led by Moses.

questions.question: In Isaiah 63:13-14, the LORD’s guidance through the wilderness is compared to what imagery?
options: A horse in the wilderness and a beast going down into the valley
A shepherd leading sheep to pasture
A mighty warrior leading an army
A river flowing through a desert
questions.correctAnswer: A horse in the wilderness and a beast going down into the valley
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 use similes of a horse and a beast to illustrate the LORD guiding His people safely and providing rest in the wilderness.

questions.question: What plea does the speaker make to the LORD in Isaiah 63:15 regarding His zeal and mercies?
options: To look down from heaven and show His mercies
To withdraw His presence forever
To punish the rebellious people immediately
To remain silent and let destiny unfold
questions.correctAnswer: To look down from heaven and show His mercies
questions.explanation: Verse 15 entreats the LORD to look down from His holy habitation and question if His mercies are restrained, implying a plea for restoration.

questions.question: In Isaiah 63:16, what titles are attributed to the LORD that affirm His eternal nature and relationship to His people?
options: Father and Redeemer, with a name from everlasting
King and Judge, ruler of all nations
Creator and Provider, maker of heaven and earth
Shepherd and Protector, guide of the flock
questions.correctAnswer: Father and Redeemer, with a name from everlasting
questions.explanation: Verse 16 calls the LORD 'our father' and 'our redeemer' and affirms His name is from everlasting, emphasizing His eternal covenant.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 63:17, the speaker asks the LORD why He has hardened their hearts and made them err from His ways.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:17 explicitly questions why the LORD has caused them to err and hardened their hearts, indicating a lament over the people's state.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:18-19, what has happened to the people of the LORD's holiness and their sanctuary?
options: They possessed it only a little while, and adversaries have trodden down the sanctuary
They have held it in peace and prosperity for many years
They abandoned the sanctuary willingly
They rebuilt the sanctuary stronger than before
questions.correctAnswer: They possessed it only a little while, and adversaries have trodden down the sanctuary
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 lament that the people possessed the holy place briefly and that enemies have trampled the sanctuary.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 63 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 63 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who is described as coming from Edom with dyed garments from Bozrah, glorious in apparel and mighty to save?
options: The Lord
A mighty warrior
A prophet of Israel
An angel of the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:1 describes the figure coming from Edom as one who speaks in righteousness and is mighty to save, identifying Him as the Lord. This aligns with other biblical depictions of God as a mighty Savior (Exodus 15:3, Revelation 19:11, Psalm 24:8, Zechariah 9:9).

questions.question: What is the significance of the red garments described in Isaiah 63:2-3?
options: They symbolize victory through judgment
They represent royal authority
They indicate mourning and sorrow
They show the wear of a long journey
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize victory through judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:2-3 explains the redness as the result of treading the winepress alone in anger and fury, symbolizing God's judgment and vengeance. This imagery is echoed in Revelation 19:13-15 and Joel 3:13 where God's judgment is portrayed as a winepress of wrath.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:4, what has come in the heart of the Lord?
options: The day of vengeance
The year of peace
The time of blessing
The season of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The day of vengeance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:4 states that the day of vengeance is in the Lord's heart and the year of His redeemed has come, indicating God's righteous judgment and salvation. This is consistent with Romans 12:19 and Hebrews 10:30 where God’s vengeance is affirmed as just.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 63:5 indicate about God's salvation?
options: God’s own arm brought salvation
Salvation comes through the prophets
Angels deliver salvation
Salvation depends on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God’s own arm brought salvation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:5 emphasizes that no help was found, so God's own arm brought salvation, highlighting divine initiative in salvation. This is consistent with Psalm 98:1 and Isaiah 59:16 where God's power alone effects salvation.

questions.question: What is promised about the LORD's lovingkindnesses in Isaiah 63:7?
options: They are abundant and merciful toward Israel
They are limited to the faithful few
They are conditional upon Israel's obedience
They are hidden from mankind
questions.correctAnswer: They are abundant and merciful toward Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:7 praises the LORD’s great goodness and multitude of lovingkindnesses toward Israel, consistent with God's covenant mercy seen in Exodus 34:6, Psalm 103:8, Lamentations 3:22, and Jeremiah 31:3.

questions.question: How is the LORD described in relation to His people in Isaiah 63:8?
options: Surely they are His people, and He is their Savior
He is a distant judge
He is a strict lawgiver
He is an indifferent creator
questions.correctAnswer: Surely they are His people, and He is their Savior
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:8 states that the LORD acknowledges His people and acts as their Savior, affirming God's personal relationship and redemption, consistent with Exodus 6:7, Isaiah 43:1, John 10:14, and Romans 11:2.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 63:9, how did the LORD respond to the affliction of His people?
options: He was afflicted with them and saved them by His angel
He abandoned them to their enemies
He punished them without mercy
He sent prophets to rebuke them only
questions.correctAnswer: He was afflicted with them and saved them by His angel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:9 reveals God’s compassion as He shares in their affliction and delivers them through His angel, showing divine presence in suffering. This theme appears in Psalm 34:18, Hebrews 4:15, Exodus 23:20, and 2 Corinthians 1:3-4.

questions.question: What was the consequence of the people's rebellion as stated in Isaiah 63:10?
options: The Holy Spirit was vexed and God became their enemy
God forgave them immediately
They received extra blessings
They were given new laws
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit was vexed and God became their enemy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:10 shows that rebellion grieved the Holy Spirit, turning God to oppose His people, consistent with Ephesians 4:30, Hebrews 10:29, Numbers 14:11, and Psalm 78:40.

questions.question: What historical event does Isaiah 63:11-12 recall to illustrate God's saving acts?
options: The Exodus led by Moses through the Red Sea
The building of Solomon's temple
The Babylonian exile
The conquest of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: The Exodus led by Moses through the Red Sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:11-12 recalls God's deliverance of Israel from Egypt through Moses and the dividing of the sea, underscoring God's saving power, as also recounted in Exodus 14:21-22, Psalm 106:9, Nehemiah 9:11, and Hebrews 11:29.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 63:14 metaphorically describe God's leading of His people?
options: Like a beast resting in the valley led by the Spirit
Like a bird soaring in the sky
Like a river flowing to the sea
Like a warrior charging into battle
questions.correctAnswer: Like a beast resting in the valley led by the Spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:14 uses the imagery of a beast resting in the valley, led by the Spirit of the LORD, to describe God’s gentle guidance, reflecting Psalm 23:2, Isaiah 40:11, Ezekiel 34:15-16, and John 10:27.

questions.question: In Isaiah 63:15, what is the speaker asking God to reveal?
options: Where is your zeal, strength, and mercies?
Why you created the heavens
How to gain material wealth
The secrets of the future
questions.correctAnswer: Where is your zeal, strength, and mercies?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:15 pleads for God to look down and reveal His zeal, strength, and mercies, reflecting a lament for God's apparent absence, paralleling Psalm 44:23-26, Lamentations 3:22-24, Habakkuk 3:2, and Joel 2:18.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 63:16 describe the LORD's relationship to Israel and Abraham?
options: The LORD is their Father and Redeemer, even if Abraham and Israel do not acknowledge them
The LORD is only the God of Abraham
The LORD is distant and unknowing
The LORD is a judge without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is their Father and Redeemer, even if Abraham and Israel do not acknowledge them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:16 affirms God's paternal and redemptive role despite human ignorance or rejection, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:6, Hosea 11:1, Romans 8:15, and Galatians 4:6.

questions.question: What is the plea made in Isaiah 63:17 regarding Israel's spiritual condition?
options: Return for your servants' sake, for Israel has erred and hardened their heart
Destroy your enemies without mercy
Ignore the people's rebellion
Bless the land with abundance
questions.correctAnswer: Return for your servants' sake, for Israel has erred and hardened their heart
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:17 asks God to return because Israel has gone astray and hardened their heart, expressing repentance and dependence on divine mercy, echoing Psalm 51:10, Jeremiah 3:22, Joel 2:13, and 2 Chronicles 7:14.

questions.question: What is said about the adversaries in Isaiah 63:18?
options: They have trodden down God's sanctuary
They have been converted to the LORD
They have fled from the land
They have been destroyed completely
questions.correctAnswer: They have trodden down God's sanctuary
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:18 laments that adversaries have trampled the sanctuary, pointing to desecration and suffering, consistent with 2 Kings 25:17-18, Ezekiel 10:18-19, Lamentations 2:7, and Psalm 74:3.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 63:19 affirm about the people in relation to God's rule?
options: They belong to God but have never been ruled over by Him
They have always been obedient to God
They have been rejected by God
They rule themselves without God's influence
questions.correctAnswer: They belong to God but have never been ruled over by Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 63:19 declares the people are God's but have not been ruled by Him nor called by His name, highlighting a failed covenant relationship, as also reflected in Jeremiah 7:23, Hosea 2:23, Ezekiel 34:2-4, and Romans 9:24.
